questions.text: The following is a victim of a firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intermediate range

 

Features of firearm injuries at various ranges-

choices.text: Grease collar
Bevelling of skull
Everted margins
CoHb (carboxy Hb)

questions.text: What characteristic is typically observed in firearm entrance wounds?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Grease collar

 

A grease collar, also referred to as marginal abrasion or bullet wipe soiling, is commonly seen in firearm entrance (entry) wounds. It is caused by the contact between the bullet and the skin, resulting in the deposition of grease, abrasion, or dirt around the wound's margins.

 

Bevelling of the skull (option b) and everted margins (option c) are characteristics typically observed in exit wounds, not entrance wounds. CoHb (option d) refers to carboxyhemoglobin levels, which are not directly associated with entrance or exit wounds.

choices.text: Tandem bullet
Dum-dum bullet
Incendiary bullet
Tumbling bullet

questions.text: The term for a bullet that is not released from a gun but is ejected out with a subsequent shot is known as a:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tandem bullet

 

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet): Bullets ejected one after the other, when the first bullet having been struck in the barrel, fails to leave the barrel and is ejected by a subsequently fired bullet. The cause is faulty ammunition or loaded firearm unused for years.

 

Choice B  (Dum Dum Bullet): Dum dum bullets, or expanding bullets, are bullets which expand or flatten easily on striking in the human body.

 

Choice C (Incendiary Buttet): Cause fire on hitting the target

 

Choice D (Tumbling Bullet): Bullet rotates end-to-end during its path

 

Core Cocept: There are two types of terms which can be confused easily as in both two bullets come out:

choices.text: Incendiary bullet
Explosive bullet
Dum-dum bullet
Tandem bullet

questions.text: Which type of bullet is designed to catch fire upon hitting the target?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Incendiary bullet

 

An incendiary bullet is designed with a tip containing self-igniting materials, such as barium nitrate and powdered aluminum and magnesium. Upon hitting the target, the bullet catches fire, resulting in additional damage.

 

Note: Dum-dum bullets (option c) are designed to expand upon striking the target and cause maximum tissue damage. Tandem bullets (option d) are known as "one-behind-other" bullets, where two bullets are ejected one after the other. This is in the case of the first bullet failing to leave the barrel and being ejected by a subsequently fired bullet.

choices.text: Dermal nitrite (Paraffin) test
Harrison and Gilroy test
Neutron activation analysis
Atomic absorption spectroscopy

questions.text: Which test is used for the detection of nitrate in firearm discharge?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dermal nitrite (Paraffin) test

 

The dermal nitrite (Paraffin) test is a test used for the detection of nitrate in firearm discharge. It involves collecting samples from the hands or other relevant surfaces of an individual suspected of discharging a firearm and analyzing them for the presence of nitrate residues.

choices.text: It contains the propellent (gun powder)
It serves as the projectile (missile)
It provides necessary muzzle velocity and striking energy
It acts as the outer covering of the cartridge

questions.text: What is the purpose of a cartridge case in firearms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It acts as the outer covering of the cartridge

 

Explanation: The cartridge case is the outer covering of the cartridge used in firearms. It holds all the components of the cartridge together and provides structural support and protection to the internal components.

 

Note: Option a describes the propellent, option b describes the projectile, and option c explains the function of the propellent in generating muzzle velocity and striking energy.

choices.text: Tandem
Dum-dum
Souvenir
Piggy

questions.text: Which of the following bullets causes maximum damage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dum-dum

 

Dum-dum bullets, also known as expanding bullets, are designed to increase in diameter and expand upon striking the target. These bullets cause maximum tissue damage due to their ability to create larger diameter wounds with limited penetration. The chiseling or cutting off of the nose tip of the jacketed bullet allows for expansion upon impact, resulting in increased damage to the surrounding tissues.

 

Option 'a' Tandem, 'c' Souvenir, and 'd' Piggy are not directly associated with causing maximum damage. Tandem refers to a configuration of two bullets being ejected one after the other, Souvenir refers to a bullet left in the body for a long time, surrounded by fibrous tissue, and Piggy is not a term associated with a specific type of bullet.

choices.text: Kennedy Phenomenon
Surgical Dilemma
Gunshot Alteration
Wound Confusion

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the difficulty in evaluating whether a gunshot wound is an entrance or an exit wound after surgical alteration or suturing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Kennedy Phenomenon

 

The Kennedy Phenomenon refers to the difficulty in determining whether a gunshot wound is an entrance or an exit wound after surgical alteration or suturing. This phenomenon arises because the surgical alteration or suturing can modify the characteristics of the wound, making it challenging to differentiate between entrance and exit wounds based on traditional indicators. It highlights the complexity involved in forensic analysis when evaluating gunshot wounds that have undergone surgical intervention.

choices.text: Brain
Spleen
Heart
Limb

questions.text: Counter coup injury is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Brain

 

Counter coup injury refers to a traumatic injury that occurs on the side of the brain opposite to the site of impact. It is caused by the brain rebounding against the inner surface of the skull after an initial impact. Counter coup injuries typically occur as a result of high-velocity forces that cause the brain to move rapidly within the skull, leading to additional injury on the opposite side of the brain from the initial impact. These injuries can include contusions, hemorrhages, lacerations, or other forms of damage. Counter coup injuries are commonly observed in situations such as motor vehicle accidents or falls where the head undergoes sudden deceleration or acceleration forces.

choices.text: Potassium chlorate
Sulphur
Potassium nitrate
Nitrocellulose

questions.text: Compound used as primer in weapon is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Potassium chlorate

 

The compound used as a primer in a weapon is potassium chlorate (option a). A primer is a component of ammunition that is responsible for initiating the firing sequence. It is typically located in the base of the cartridge case and is ignited by a firing pin or striking mechanism.

 

Potassium chlorate is a chemical compound that contains oxygen and is highly reactive. It is commonly used as an oxidizer in the primer composition of ammunition. When the primer is struck, it generates a small flame or spark due to the rapid decomposition of potassium chlorate. This flame then ignites the propellant, initiating the combustion process that propels the projectile out of the firearm.

 

The other options mentioned - sulfur (option b), potassium nitrate (option c), and nitrocellulose (option d) - are also commonly used in the manufacturing of ammunition and propellants, but they are not specifically used as primers. Therefore, the correct answer is option a, potassium chlorate.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates that gunshot wound was likely homicidal?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Multiple gunshot wounds on the body of victim.

choices.text: Revolver
Shotgun
Automatic pistol
Machine gun

questions.text: ‘Paradox gun’ is a?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shotgun

 

Explanation: A "paradox gun" refers to a specific type of shotgun design. It is a shotgun with a rifled barrel, which is unusual as shotguns typically have smoothbore barrels. The rifling in the barrel of a paradox gun gives it the ability to fire both shot (multiple projectiles) and a single solid projectile accurately. This dual-purpose capability makes it unique compared to traditional shotguns. While shotguns can have various configurations, including single-shot, double-barreled, pump-action, or semi-automatic, the term "paradox gun" specifically refers to the design of a shotgun with a rifled barrel. Therefore, the correct answer is B. Shotgun.

choices.text: Primary impact injury
Secondary impact injuries
Tertiary impact injuries
Secondary injury

questions.text: Which type of pedestrian injury is caused by the initial contact with the vehicle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primary impact injury

 

Primary impact injuries in pedestrian accidents are produced by the initial contact with the vehicle. These injuries can take the form of abrasions, lacerations, or contusions. In cases of pedestrian accidents, it is common for both legs to sustain fractures in the region of impact with the bumper of the vehicle, which is often referred to as "bumper fracture." Therefore, the correct answer is a. Primary impact injury.

choices.text: Falanga
Telefono
Quirofana
Both A and B

questions.text: What term describes the beating of the soles of the feet with a blunt object?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Falanga

 

Falanga, also known as Falolka or Bautiflada, refers to the beating of the soles of the feet with a blunt object. It is a form of physical abuse where the victim's feet are intentionally struck, often resulting in severe pain and injury.

 

Note: Telefono (option b) refers to the simultaneous beating of both ears with palms, while Quirofana (option c) involves beating on the abdomen while the upper half of the body lies unsupported on a table.

choices.text: Broad end of the entry point in bullet injury
Narrow end of the entry point in bullet injury
Exit point of bullet
Depressed fracture of the skull

questions.text: Bevelling of skull is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Exit point of bullet

  • Wound of entrance shows a punched in (clean) hole in the outer table. Cone shaped bone is detached from the inner table forming a crater that is larger than the hole of the outer table and shows beveling (sloping surface).
  • Thus, looking from outside, entrance wound is clean cut hole and exit wound is bevelled opening.

choices.text: Wads are made of hard and heavy materials such as metal or wood
Wads are present in all types of firearms, including rifles and pistols
Wads are used to increase the velocity and accuracy of the shot
Wads can travel a distance of up to 6 meters

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about wads used in shot gun cartridges?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wads can go up to 6 meters

 

Wads are soft and light materials used to keep things in place, such as in shot gun cartridges. They are typically made of materials like cardboard, felt, cork, plastic, or paper. Wads are specifically designed for shot guns and are placed between the gun powder and pellets or above the pellets. Their diameter is slightly larger than the bore of the gun to seal the cartridge and prevent the escape of gases. Wads are primarily used to allow optimum pressure to develop, assist in lubrication, and prevent the escape of gases. It should be noted that wads are not heavy or hard enough to cause serious injury.

choices.text: Flame
Hot gases
Smoke
Unburnt powder

questions.text: In firearm injury, entry-wound blackening is due to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Smoke

  • Singeing is due to Flame.
  • Blackening is due to Smoke.
  • Tattoing is due to Unburnt powder discharged from the firearm weapon.
  • Blackening can be wiped away but Tattooing Cannot be wiped away.
  • Blackening and Tattooing, both are demonstrated by Infrared photography on both skin and clothes.

choices.text: Charcoal
Lead peroxide
Potassium nitrate
Sulphur

questions.text: All are components of gun-powder EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lead peroxide

  • Lead peroxide is a main component of Primer, and it is not a component of gun-powder.

CORE CONCEPT

 

Gun powder:

  • Black gun powder contains Potassium nitrate 75% + Charcoal 15% + Sulphur 10%
  • Smokeless Powder is of following types:
  • Single Base: Contains nitrocellulose,
  • Double Base: contains nitrocellulose + nitroglycerine
  • Triple Base: Contains Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine + nitroguanidine
  • Primers: lead peroxide + lead styphnate + tetrazene + barium nitrate

Other options:

 

Option A. Charcoal; Option C. Potassium nitrate; Option D. Sulphur all are components of gun powder but the question is asking which is not a component of gunpowder.

questions.text: The distance between the victim and firearm in the below image:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2m-4m

  • The image shows a central rat hole wound (wound with irregular margins resembling as bitten by a rat) with a few satellite wounds.
  • Rat hole wound occurs in gunshot wound after 30 cm
  • Satellite wounds occur after 2m.
  • After 4 m there is only individual pellet wounds and no central wound.
  • Since the image shows central rat hole wound as well as satellite wounds, the distance is 2m-4m.
